title: 115_hr1615
content: The Act titled "Get Foreign Money Out of U.S. Elections Act" applies a ban on contributions and expenditures by foreign nationals to domestic corporations that are foreign-controlled, foreign-influenced, and foreign-owned. The "Get Foreign Money Out of U.S. Elections Act" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to ban contributions and expenditures by foreign nationals to domestic corporations that are foreign-controlled. The "Get Foreign Money Out of U.S. Elections Act" prohibits foreign nationals from owning or controlling voting shares in domestic corporations involved in U.S. elections. The "Get Foreign Money Out of U.S. Elections Act" prohibits foreign nationals from controlling the decision-making process of corporations involved in U.S. elections. The "Get Foreign Money Out of U.S. Elections Act" requires the chief executive officer of a corporation to file a certification with the Commission before making any contribution, donation, expenditure, or disbursement for an election for Federal office. This certification must confirm that the corporation is not prohibited from such activities under the Act. The Act will take effect regardless of whether the Federal Election Commission has issued regulations to implement the amendments. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF APPLICATION OF FOREIGN MONEY BAN TO CERTAIN DISBURSEMENTS AND ACTIVITIES. The amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits disbursements to political committees that accept non-compliant donations. Additionally, a corporate PAC must certify to the Commission before making contributions or expenditures during the year. The fund must certify that all decision-makers are U.S. citizens or lawful residents, no foreign nationals influence decisions, and foreign national board members abstain from voting on fund matters.
